entry.title: Re: 客户对S/4HANA Public Cloud的账套需求
entry.content:
Hello @JuliaLu 

To set up 0L (local GAAP), 2L (Austrian GAAP), and 4G (Chinese GAAP) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you need to:

Scope ledgers during initial setup (CBC):

    • Activate J58 (0L), 1GA (2L), and 2VA (3L – used as 4G).

Ledgers are fixed after go-live.

  1. Assign accounting principles (e.g. LocalGAAP, ATGAAP, CNAP) to the correct ledgers and company codes via SSCUI 101087.
  2. Charts of accounts:Only one operational CoA is allowed. Use alternative G/L accounts and group account numbers for local and group needs.

Consolidation:
Use Group Reporting (scope items 1SG, 3SG) for Austrian and Chinese GAAP group reporting. Map local accounts to group FS items.

Reporting:
Use standard apps by ledger and consolidation unit.

Refer to below helpful SAP Documentations

SAP Help: Parallel Accounting in Public Cloud

Preparing for Universal Parallel Accounting

2844132 - The field "G/L" is greyed out in app Create Incoming Invoices

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: BADI Recommendation for Vendor Balance Validation in...
entry.content:
Hi @PTiwari 

Thanks for outlining the requirement.

To enable you restrict FB65 postings based on vendor balances, you can use the following BAdI:

BAdI: MM_IV_ITEM_BADI
Method: CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE

This process allows you implement a logic that retrieves the vendor’s current balance and raises an error if the balance is negative. The check should ensure the balance is ≥ 0 before allowing the invoice to post.


Before you proceed, please ensure that this BADI is available in your tenant via the Custom Logic app. If it is not available, an alternative would be to use a BRF+ validation or a custom extension via BTP.

Below are detailed steps that might be helpful in achieving CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE method:

  1. First, retrieve the vendor number from the invoice header.
  2. Second, call BAPI_VENDOR_GETDETAIL or use CDS view I_Supplier / I_SupplierCompany. This however depends on your system.
  3. Third, check the current balance of the vendor from the BSEG or BSIK/BSIS relevant source. Note that the cloud-friendly version is achieved via CDS or public APIs.
  4. Finally, if balance < 0, raise an error using RAISE EXCEPTION or MESSAGE.

Please note that in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, the use of custom code is restricted to released BADIs. Check if MM_IV_ITEM_BADI or MM_IV_HEADER_BADI is released in your system under Extensibility > Custom Logic app.

If not available, an alternative approach is to:

  • Use the Business Rule Framework (BRF+) for validation (if FB65 flows through MM logic).
  • Otherwise, implement pre-checks via a custom CDS-based RAP object or side-by-side check in BTP.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Warm regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: CCM Workflow Report
entry.content:
Hi,

As of now there isn’t a standard report or app in CCM (Continuous Control Monitoring) that directly shows pending workflows per user out of the box.

However, you can try checking the My Inbox app (if configured) for user-specific workflows, or use transaction SWI5 or SWI1 in the backend to track workflow items by user.

If you're using GRC with CCM, you might also be able to create a custom report using tables like SWWUSERWI or SWWIHEAD to list pending items per user.

Would recommend checking with your BASIS or workflow admin to confirm what’s active in your system.

Hope this helps!

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 - DTW - Purchasing UOM Codes
entry.content:
Hi @bbranco 

Thanks again for all the details and sorry to hear that this has been taking your time. you're actually quite close to solving the issue.

To answer your questions:

  • Yes, UoMEntry 7 is correct for 6-CS/PK based on your OUOM screenshot.
  • While assigning the UoM group in the item master is necessary, you also need to populate the UoM relationships using DTW to load entries into ITM12.
  • Manually editing the group in the UI won’t populate the UoM lines. So, a DTW upload for ITM12 is still required.

My suggestion to get this working, make sure to:

  1. First load OITM with the correct UoMGroupEntry.
  2. Then load ITM12 with all the required UoM types (I, P, and S) and correct UoMEntry (which is 7 for 6-CS/PK).
  3. Define the unit conversion ratio in the BaseQty and AltQty columns for example 6 EACH = 1 CS/PK.

I hope this can help you close the case.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Clean Core + BTP = Future-Ready ERP: Streamline Upgrades and Accelerate AI Adoption
entry.content:
In the rapidly evolving enterprise landscape, maintaining agility while preserving system integrity is critical. SAP has introduced the Clean Core concept to address this need — a strategic approach that encourages minimal customizations to the core SAP ERP system, while shifting extensions and innovations to cloud-native platforms like SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). This not only simplifies system upgrades and lowers technical debt but also enhances long-term scalability and innovation potential.

What is SAP Clean Core?

SAP Clean Core refers to the principle of keeping the core SAP ERP system as close to standard as possible. It encourages:

  • Avoiding intrusive custom code directly within the ERP core.
  • Using side-by-side extensibility for custom functionalities.
  • Adopting SAP-approved frameworks and tools for integration and extension.

Mainly, it ensures that customers can utilize out-of-the-box functionality. It facilitates easier integration of AI and other emerging technologies.

How BTP Helps Mitigate Clean Core Challenges

SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) plays a central role in enabling a clean core by offering services and tools that support side-by-side extensions. Here's how BTP mitigates clean core challenges:

  • Application Development & Integration: BTP provides environments (e.g., SAP Build, CAP, RAP, Kyma) to develop and deploy custom apps without touching the ERP core.
  • Event-Driven Architecture: Through SAP Event Mesh or SAP Integration Suite, events from ERP can trigger actions on BTP for loosely coupled integrations.
  • Low-code/No-code Tools: Business users can innovate quickly using SAP Build Apps and Process Automation, bypassing core modifications.
  • Data & Analytics: With SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Analytics Cloud, businesses can build advanced analytics models and dashboards independent of the core.
  • Security and Governance: Centralized identity management and audit services ensure compliance without overloading ERP layers.

By decoupling custom logic and innovations from the ERP core, BTP ensures faster deployments and safer upgrades.

In essence, a clean core approach clears out the complexities and legacy issues that can hinder the adoption of AI, providing a stable, standardized, and agile foundation upon which an organization can build intelligent, AI-powered solutions.

entry.title: Re: [Crystal Reports] ERROR 512: Print Engine could not o...
entry.content:
What version of crpe32 are you using?

A quick Google search found this:

CRPE error 512 in Crystal Reports typically indicates a problem with the Print Engine, specifically that it failed to open or initialize. This can manifest as PE_ERR_ENGINENOTOPEN or other similar error messages related to the print engine. The issue is often related to outdated components, incorrect configuration, or problems with the underlying database connection. 

 
 
Here's a more detailed breakdown:
Possible Causes:
  • Print Engine Issues:
    The core problem often lies within the Crystal Reports Print Engine itself, which might not be properly initialized or might be encountering errors during its startup sequence. 
     

     

    •  
    • Database Connection Problems:
      If the report relies on a database, errors in the database connection string, missing drivers, or incorrect database configurations can trigger this error. 
       
    •  
    • Outdated Components:
      Using outdated versions of Crystal Reports components, like the Print Engine APIs (which were retired in later versions), can lead to compatibility issues and this error. 
       
    •  
    • System Date Issues:
      In some cases, changing the system date, particularly after a certain date like January 19, 2038, can cause the print engine to fail. 
       
    •  
    • Incorrect Report Loading:
      Loading a report with an invalid path or if the report file is corrupted can also trigger the error. 
       

       

      •  
        Troubleshooting Steps:
        1. 1. Check the Report File and Path:
          Verify that the report file exists and that the path specified in the application is correct. 
           

           

          •  
          • 2. Verify Database Connection:
            Double-check the database connection string, credentials, and ensure the database server is accessible. 
             
          •  
          • 3. Update Crystal Reports:
            Ensure you are using a supported version of Crystal Reports and that all necessary updates and service packs are installed. 
             
          •  
          • 4. Consider RDC or .NET:
            If you are using the Print Engine APIs, consider migrating to the Report Designer Component (RDC) or the .NET component for newer versions of Crystal Reports. 
             
          •  
          • 5. Review the Error Message:
            Carefully examine the full error message for more specific details about the cause, such as the specific function failing or the error code within the Print Engine. 
             
          •  
          • 6. Consult SAP Community:
            If you are using SAP Crystal Reports, consult the SAP Community forums for solutions specific to your version and error scenario, according to the SAP Community. 
             
          •  
          • 7. Check for Date Conflicts:
            If you recently changed the system date, ensure that it's within the supported range for Crystal Reports. 
             

             

          •

          •

          •

entry.title: IAS (OIDC / OpenID) with ABAP Cloud Developer Trial 2023
entry.content:
This is not an official how-to document but rather sharing experience with the community. This is my first initial setup and will update this as I do more testing with OIDC on ABAP.

At least this is another resource for your journey to setting up OIDC on ABAP. 

My setup at home:

  1. ABAP Cloud Developer Trial 2023 (docker)
  2. BTP Trial Subaccount
  3. Cloud Identity Services Trial

My home setup diagram:

Other requirements:

  • Need to know your home router capabilities.
    • My router (Asus) can handle DDNS
    • It can utilize Let’s encrypt for signing Router certificate.
    • Need to know how to port forward to the ABAP TLS port eg: port 50001
  • You may need Proxy information for your ABAP outbound. Since this is my own home ABAP lab, I don’t use any proxy.
  • Some excellent references and blogs that helped me:
    • ABAP Cloud Developer Trial 2023 Available Now
    • Configuring OIDC between SAP IAS and S/4HANA (ABAP) in a RISE AWS Environment
    • Sign up for a free Trial Account for SAP BTP
    • OpenID Connect for AS ABAP
    • Note 3111813 - OpenID Connect (OIDC): Troubleshooting Note

Lessons learned:

This is not SAML.

IAS need to be able to reach my ABAP system, and since it’s hosted in my Docker Server. Port forwarding is needed to my Docker Server.

Since IAS need to access ABAP, I assumed self-signed SSL Server certificate would not do. It will need ABAP SSL Server to be publicly signed somehow. I found a workaround; my Asus router already have DDNS feature that can also register and utilize a Free Certificate from Let’s Encrypt.

So, after setting up the DDNS, I can use the registered hostname as

https://abapserver.asuscomm.com:50001

The router needs to be configured for port forwarding to ensure that it is reachable from the internet.

Exported the Let's encrypt certificate from ASUS router, then using openssl and sapgenpse , I created a brand new SAPSSLS.PSE with the signed certificate, key and chain certs, and replace it in STRUST.  Here’s the steps.

 

Setting up Cloud Identity Services

1. Create a test user (IAS --> Users & Authorization --> User Management).

This user will need to exist in the ABAP system too. I just created a user jon doe with email jon.doe@xyz.com and make sure it’s verified. This email will need to match the user in ABAP.

 

2. Setup the ABAP as an Application in IAS. IAS --> Application & Resources --> Application and click the Create button.

 

3. Go into the application which is listed on the left side. My example is called ABAP_TRIAL.

4. Go to the OpenID Connection Configuration under Trust.

5. Enter any name, and the part for "Redirect URIs" is important.

The ABAP redirect URI is  /sap/public/bc/sec/oidc/redirect

Some other systems may use /oauth2/callback,  but ABAP does not.

So, for my example it’ll be https://abapserver.asuscomm.com:50001/sap/public/bc/sec/oidc/redirect

Then save it.

6. Select the Single Sign-On --> Subject Name Identifier. I selected Identity Directory with Value Email then save it. I need email as the identifier, this will map nicely with ABAP configuration later.

7. Scroll down to Trust --> Application APIs --> Client Authentication

8. For my initial test, I’m just going to use secrets (password). Scroll down to Secrets and Click the Add button.

9. Enter some description and expiry and select OpenID and save.

10. The next pop up is important. Need to copy and paste it in your notepad for later reference. You can’t retrieve it later.

11. Make sure to save it.

12. Next go to IAS --> Application & Resources tab --> Tenant Settings

13. Select the Single Sign-On --> OpenID Connect Configuration. Cut and paste  this information into your notepad. You will need this later.

14. Next step is to download the public TLS certificate of the IAS tenant. ABAP will need this certificate.

14.1 While at IAS tenant , go to the browser URL and click the front of the URL.  

14.2 Then click certificate is valid

14.3 Select the trial hostname and click the export button and save it to a file. 

15. This file certificate file will be needed to be loaded in ABAP Strust SSL Client Anonymous later.

ABAP OpenID Setup

16. Logon to the ABAP system. Create a test user in ABAP SU01. In my example I copied the existing DEVELOPER user in ABAP and created Jon Doe with email jon.doe@xyz.com .

17. Activate the three required OIDC services. Go to transaction SICF  , enter the Service Name = OIDC and execute

18. Select oidc and right click and activate service

Make sure you select the 2nd Yes to activate all services under oidc

19. Validate all the three services (logout/logoutbc/redirect) under oidc is active.

20. Before you quit SICF, does your ABAP need proxy server? If it does, then go to Menu --> Client --> Proxy Settings

21. In global settings – check the Proxy settings is active and go to HTTPS protocol tab next

22. Enter the proxy server required and save it. 

23. Go to transaction STRUST  and double click the SSL Client SSL Client (Anonymous) and click the change button

24. Click menu Certificate --> Import

 25. Import the previously downloaded certificate from IAS (e.g. _trial-accounts.ondemand.com.cer), then click “add to certificate list”. And save it. You might need to restart your ICM too. 

26. Go to Transaction SOIDC and click the Change button.

 27. Then at Configurations section, there are some additional buttons. Click the new document button and enter the Issuer URL.

URL must not have forward slash / at the end.

Get this info from step 13. Make sure both checkboxes are checked. This allows us to pull in the other URL via discovery.

28. If there are no errors, then it will pull the URL and web key set automatically. Else you need to manually add it.

29. Go back to the Secrets that was copied in step 8. Copy and paste the Client ID into the Client ID field.

30. Leave everything else as default, then scroll down the page and check the Interactive (OIDC Logon) . The authorization and token endpoint should be pre-filled from discovery.  Enter the Redirect URL (the public access ABAP hostname and URI) , eg for my case :

       https://abapserver.asuscomm.com:50001/sap/public/bc/sec/oidc/redirect

31. Next click the Client Secret change button.

32. Go back to the Secrets that was copied in step 8. Copy and paste the Client Secret into the New Client Secret field.

33. Make sure to save the form.

34. Validate the configuration. Select the Issuer and click Validation button and ensure no errors.

35. Since there are no warnings found, the configuration needs to be activated. Select the configuration and click “Set Default Interactive Configuration”. If button is grayed out, make sure to click the save button first and try again.

36. The configuration should have “Default Interactive Configuration” checked. We should be ready for testing.

 

Testing Steps

Just to summarized what was done so far.

  • Network port forwarding
  • Setup Cloud Identity Service
  • Setup ABAP OIDC Connect

37. Start-up Chrome as Incognito and enter ABAP Fiori URL for testing (Fiori already activated in the ABAP cloud trial).

eg:

https://abapserver.asuscomm.com:50001/sap/bc/ui2/flp

38. This should go to ABAP first then it will redirect to IAS and get the IAS logon screen:

If you get error before reaching the logon page, then most likely your redirect URL is incorrect.

Unfortunately for me, this error doesn’t get recorded in IAS.

But check:

  • ABAP redirect SICF services is active
  • ABAP redirect URI is accessible from Internet
  • ABAP redirect URI entered in
    • IAS as in step 5
    • ABAP as in step 31
  • URI does not have trailing slash /

39. Login with the test user id.

40. IAS will do it’s OIDC magic and ideally should log you in directly into Fiori.

entry.title: SAP CPI – How to Avoid Escaping XML-Like Strings Inside JSON/XML Fields During Message Mapping
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I’m facing an issue in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) where my integration needs to pass an XML-formatted string as part of the payload, but CPI escapes all angle brackets (<, >) during processing. This causes problems on the receiving end, which expects raw XML-like data inside a single tag, not escaped or parsed.

🔍Scenario:

I receive a JSON payload that contains a field like this:

 
<li-code lang="json">
{ "MessageBody": "<STATUS><CODE>200</CODE><MESSAGE>Success</MESSAGE></STATUS>" }​


When this is passed through the standard JSON to XML conversion in CPI, the resulting XML is:

<MessageBody><STATUS><CODE>200</CODE><MESSAGE>Success</MESSAGE></STATUS></MessageBody>

However, what I actually need is:

<MessageBody><STATUS><CODE>200</CODE><MESSAGE>Success</MESSAGE></STATUS></MessageBody>

But I do not want CPI to interpret this as a nested XML structure that generates child nodes like MessageBody/STATUS/CODE/... in the XSD. I want MessageBody to remain a flat string field, preserving its XML-like content as a raw string.

Goal:

  • Treat the content of MessageBody as a plain string, not XML structure.

  • Avoid escaping of <, > symbols.

  • Ensure that the target schema sees MessageBody as a single flat field, not a complex nested element.

    What I Tried:

    I tried using CDATA in my groovy script but after the message mapping step the value results in escaped characters.

     
def body = message.getBody(String)
def wrapped = "<MessageBody><![CDATA[${body}]]></MessageBody>."

Would appreciate any ideas, workarounds, or best practices others have used in similar scenarios.

Thanks in advance! 🙏

entry.title: The SAP Activate Road Maps for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
As you might have noticed, with the release of the SAP Activate road maps, Provisioning Enablement for SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP, we now have six road maps related to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. You might be wondering: What are the differences between these roadmaps, and which one should I use?"

To help you navigate these road maps, I have created a brief overview of each, highlighting their purposes. By understanding these differences, you'll be better equipped to select the most suitable roadmap for your specific needs.

 

SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape)

This is the established roadmap for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, used successfully for several years. It is regularly updated and enhanced and will continue to be the go-to road map for implementing or expanding the use of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. In SAP Cloud ALM, it can be combined with other roadmaps to suit the needs of your implementation.

SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2-system landscape)

This roadmap originates from the era of the 2-system landscape and is maintained primarily to support expanding countries or scope for existing SAP S/4HANA Cloud customers who have not yet migrated to a 3-system landscape. Although provisioning functionalities have been removed, the roadmap still offers valuable guidance. However, it cannot be combined with other roadmaps within SAP Cloud ALM.

Provisioning Enablement for SAP Cloud ERP

Introduced in conjunction with the unified provisioning capabilities for SAP Business Suite, this roadmap guides customers through the provisioning and initial system access across various business suite products. Upon system provisioning, customers will receive a welcome email containing a link to this roadmap. The roadmap's final task directs users to the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP roadmap for further guidance. Please note, this roadmap is not available within SAP Cloud ALM and is intended for use through the SAP Road Map Viewer. For more information, see Blog NEW SAP Activate Provisioning Road Map for SAP Business Suite Packages.

SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP

This roadmap is a continuation the Provisioning Enablement for SAP Cloud ERP road map, so it excludes the Discover phase and initial provisioning tasks. It covers implementation scenarios related to SAP Business Suite packages such as Finance and Supply Chain which extend beyond the core SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition functionality. While not presented as a standalone roadmap in SAP Cloud ALM, an implementation-specific scope can be built using combinable roadmaps based on your implementation scope. A common combination might include SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP Concur, and—importantly—an Adoption Plan, which should always be incorporated.

SAP Activate for the Intelligent Enterprise

This roadmap includes SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Concur, along with selected elements from SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass. While it remains available as a single roadmap in SAP Cloud ALM, it is recommended to leverage SAP Cloud ALM’s combinable roadmap feature to design a project that precisely fits your implementation scope.

SAP Activate for Upgrade of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape)

The upgrade guidance is detailed within this roadmap and should be reviewed at least four weeks before each upgrade. It is accessible as a single roadmap both in the Road Map Viewer and SAP Cloud ALM. To ensure efficient management of resources and timelines leading up to your production upgrade, it is strongly recommended to leverage the project management capabilities available within SAP Cloud ALM.

I hope that his helps. Please leave your comments below.

Thanks,

Dan Ciecko

SAP Activate Product Manager 

 

To learn more about the combinable feature in SAP Cloud ALM, see the links below.

  • Cross-solution SAP Activate Road Maps with Cloud ALM
  • Combining Activate Roadmaps In SAP Cloud ALM

entry.content:

The problem with using temp tables is usually permissions and the temp table name.

CR can't handle the random generated temp name.

What's happening is your table links were deleted which is why you see 2 SELECT statements.

What you may want to do is dump the data into a DataSet() and then set location to the DS in code, that way the data is retrieved from the DB outside of CR. entry.title: Re: LTL version supported for Sybase ASE 16.0 and later v...
entry.content:
FWIW,

That LTL Compatibility matrix (Repserver Design Guide) is a reference for Replication Server and the standalone Rep Agent software.

The standalone Rep Agent software was used against heterogeneous PDBs (eg, DB2, Oracle and MS SQL Server).  I say 'was' because heterogeneous db support was officially killed a few years ago, while actual/new development on the standalone Rep Agent software ended even further back (15.7 SP 20x).

The lack of new standalone Rep Agent software development appears to coincide with the lack of updates to that LTL Compatibility matrix.

--------------

If you have a support contract you may be able to a) search for KBs that address the issue or b) open a case with tech support.

In the meantime you could hobble together bit-n-pieces: a) (ASE) dbcc gettrunc output includes the repagent's LTL version (at least when running in LTL mode); b) the ASE errorlog will list repagent and repserver LTL versions in a warning message when the repagent's LTL version is greater than the repserver's LTL version.  With this info it would be possible to fill in an LTL compatibility matrix by testing all of your ASE/repagent versions against all of your Repserver versions.

entry.title: Re: Missing point of configuration to assign the edocumen...
entry.content:
Hi @Ester2 

You're absolutely right with your findings.

Please note, the configuration activity Assign eDocument Type to Accounting Document Type (T003EDOCV) is only available for standard FI and SD billing document types in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition. Unfortunately, FI‑CA document types are not supported for this mapping in Public Cloud as of now which is controlled by scope items like 5XU and 78L. 

The following are the facts:

  • FI‑CA invoices are currently treated under the generic SII Outgoing Invoice classification for eDocument processing.
  • There’s no available scope item or configuration toggle to assign a specific SII eDocument type for FI‑CA source documents (unlike the on‑premise SPRO configuration).

That behaviour is consistent with the current SAP’s delivered model in Public Cloud. If it’s a critical legal requirement, it might need to be raised as a customer enhancement request with SAP.

The following documents will help you answer potential further questions.

Assigning eDocument Type to Accounting Document Type (Mandatory)

Electronic Invoicing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition

Hope that clarifies things. happy to assist further for your specific local compliance scenario.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
The 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition contains enhancements to popular AI features and new natural language interaction options that help you work more intelligently and intuitively.

We’ve spent the past 6 months since the 2502 release working with your feedback – from beta programs, to roundtable discussions in the Public Cloud Practitioner Forum, to one-on-one meetings with customers – to learn how we can help you achieve more with the help of AI in your system. Let’s take a look at what’s new, update you on the commercialization of some features, and give you resources for getting involved with our upcoming beta program. 

Natural language filtering now supports a wider range of queries

The AI-assisted easy filter (first released in 2502) enables you to filter list reports in your SAP Fiori elements-based apps using natural language. This simplifies how you access the information you need and reduces the training time required to pick up new applications delivered by SAP.

AI-assisted easy filter enables natural language filtering of pages with lists of business objects. Here the user can filter for a given sold-to party using plain language rather than needing to know its key..

For 2508, we’ve made a number of enhancements to make interactions with AI-assisted easy filter even more intuitive:

  1. Tables can be filtered without needing to know an object’s specific key. Instead, simply enter the name of the object you are looking for. The AI-assisted easy filter will map that text to the intended key and apply it to the filter fields for you, which is a much more natural way to search for information. In the event that there are multiple keys with similar names, you will receive results filtered for those names. As before, you can always refine your results in the input field or using the classic filtering.
  2. We’ve also worked to ensure parity between the filter fields that can be applied using the AI-assisted easy filter and the classic filter bar. Some users had reported that, in some cases, AI-assisted easy filter would not apply queries to certain filters. This was caused by the fact that some of the filter fields used navigation paths to different entities instead of the main entity for the app. This scenario is now supported and you can filter on any property present in the classic filter bar.

My Home Personalization with Insights Cards supports more apps and a new way to query for cards

The ability to create Insights cards and quickly add them to My Home now supports 20 SAP Fiori apps.

AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for Insights cards was released as a Joule capability as part of its 2503 release. The functionality allows end users to query Joule for business data they regularly need using natural language. The output is displayed as a card that can be added to their My Home page for easy reference. This makes it easier for users to access information they need to make everyday business decisions and move processes forward.

This functionality was initially limited to 9 applications. With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, this coverage has been extended to 11 additional applications. This gives users easier and wider access to the business data that is important to them. AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for Insights cards now supports the following applications:

  1. Find Maintenance Order
  2. Find Maintenance Order and Operation
  3. Maintain Bill Of Material
  4. Manage Business Partner Master Data
  5. Manage Customer Returns
  6. Manage Manual Reservations
  7. Manage Material Coverage (Version 2)
  8. Manage Outbound Deliveries
  9. Manage Product Master Data
  10. Manage Purchase Orders (Version 2)
  11. Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional
  12. Manage Sales Orders
  13. Manage Sales Orders - Version 2
  14. Manage Sales Quotation - Version 2
  15. Manage Supplier Master Data
  16. Manage Usage Decisions
  17. Material Documents Overview
  18. Project Control - Enterprise Projects
  19. Reproceess Failed Material Movements
  20. Supplier Invoices List (Version 2)

Users can now use natural language to create and add Insights Cards directly in My Home.

For the 2508 release, we have also introduced a new way to create Insights cards using natural language: you can access the feature directly from My Home. This gives users the flexibility to choose the personalization option that works best for them, giving them access to the information they need at a glance.

If you'd like to read even more exciting updates about features and functionality included in the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, check out the following fantastic blogs from my colleagues:

  • For a general overview of new functionality: Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release 
  • For a few more AI uses cases, some focused on particular business processes: Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 

Commercialization update: New Base AI includes common AI functions at no additional cost

For the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a number of AI solutions have been added to its Base AI offering. This means that you can use the features absolutely free of charge. You simply need to sign the SAP AI terms here and SAP will handle the activation for you.

Included in the Base AI offering for this release are AI-assisted easy filter and AI-assisted smart summarization, as well as AI-assisted enterprise search (which allows you to look up data from the search in My Home). Give them a try!

Try out upcoming AI innovations in the 2508 beta

For customers looking to try out the absolute latest in AI innovations, registration for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition beta is still open. This is your opportunity to try out and give feedback on new use cases for AI in your system. The solutions up for beta testing are free to use for the duration of the program.  Below is a preview of some of the features that will be available. Please note: Customer/partner participation will be at the discretion of the Beta Testing Program team. Participants must use SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition productively. Future developments are at the discretion of SAP and their details and delivery dates may be changed at any time.

Resolve situations directly in My Home without navigating to applications

AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home allows you to quickly take action on business processes that need your attention directly in My Home..

The Situations tab in My Home provides quick summaries of business processes that need to be addressed in your system. Previously, this meant reading the alert on the tile, navigating to the required app(s), and making the required changes. With AI-assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home, we’re streamlining how you take action on these scenarios. You’ll now be able to see a summary of the situation, start the relevant business process from quick actions on the card, and even make changes to the business data all without leaving your My Home page. This allows you to stay on top of your business and resolve potential issues even faster.

Streamline data entry in object pages

AI-assisted easy fill streamlines data entry by populating object pages based on natural language input (for example: emails or messages from colleagues).

Depending on your business scenario, SAP Fiori object pages can sometimes be quite complex. Data entry might mean filling a field at the top of the screen, scrolling for several sections to add more information, and so on. AI-assisted easy fill enables you to enter your updates into a single field using natural language. The solution then maps your input to the proper fields, highlights any potential inconsistencies that may need to be addressed, and – after your review – updates the fields. This will help speed up data entry and reduce training time for new users.

Resolve error messages with AI assistance

AI-assisted error explanation provides resolution recommendations to error and warning messages in your system.

Learning new business processes can be tricky. AI-assisted error explanation uses AI to generate explanations and suggest resolutions for errors that are triggered in your system. This streamlines how you handle errors and reduces training time, making you more productive and helping you pick up processes even faster; in addition to reducing your organization’s support load.

Search for applications you need using natural language

AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications allows you to search for applications using natural language.

When learning a new business process or stepping into a new role, it can sometimes be challenging to find the exact application you need to carry out a task. With AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications, you can search for the app you need using natural language. Simply type in what you need to do and get served the required application, which you can add to your My Home page with a single click. This allows you to access the applications you need without needing to know the exact application name.

We want to hear from you!

Whether you take advantage of the new free features in the Base AI package, subscribe to cutting edge technologies, or choose to take part in a beta program; we want to hear what you think about these solutions! Give them a try and share your feedback below or with the product team. Your experience is critical to understanding how we can make these innovations even better for you.

When you’re ready to get involved, you can:

  1. Register to use base AI features
  2. Sign up for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition beta
  3. Join the Public Cloud Practitioner Forum (for customers live on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

Happy experimenting! We’ll be back with another update for the 2602 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 - DTW - Purchasing UOM Codes
entry.content:
Hi Brian,

Thanks for the update, and you're on the right track.

However, the key information you're missing is that the conversion factor between the BaseQty and AltQty is not stored in ITM12. Instead, it is defined in the UoM Group setup, particularly in the table OUOM and UOM1, which are used during item master setup and control how many base units are in an alternate unit.

Please note: If the BaseQty/AltQty mapping was never set in the UoM Group, you’ll get the item-UoM relationship, but the system won’t understand the conversion you require, which might be why DTW or UoM behaviour is inconsistent.

Moving forward, the ITM12 table reflects the relationship between the item and the UoM entries, but it doesn’t store the actual conversion factors (BaseQty/AltQty).

Those are defined in the UoM Group setup itself and specifically in the UoM Group Master, which is stored in tables like OUOM/UOM1.

I will suggest checking the following:

  1. Go into the UoM Group definition for 6-CS/PK and make sure that:
    • BaseQty = 6 (i.e., 6 EACH in 1 CASE)
    • AltQty = 1
  2. Double-check that the item 20011C is assigned to the correct UoM Group (6-CS/PK) and that the Purchasing/Sales UoMs align with the group.

Once the UoM Group is set up properly, DTW or manual entry will respect the Base/Alt conversion logic.

 

Let me know if this helps solve that issue.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: sap a]Ariba integration with Sap Business one
entry.content:
Hi @Babatunde_Akinboye 

Thank you for your question.

In a standard SAP Ariba to SAP Business One integration, the RFQ process is typically initiated from SAP Ariba. Ariba is built for supplier collaboration and sourcing, so it’s the best place to manage RFQs and quotations. Once a supplier is selected, the quotation can be converted into a Purchase Requisition or Purchase Order, which is then transmitted to SAP Business One for execution.

I've also attached a very simplified architecture diagram to illustrate the flow between the systems, showing how Ariba communicates with SAP Business One via CIG or the Integration Framework.

 

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Using conda-forge in SAP Business Application Studio – my notes
entry.content:
In my previous blog posts, I focused on Using Python in SAP Business Application Studio and Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio with Python's virtual environments. But SAP Business Application Studio (referred to as "BAS" below) also allows you to work with the Conda environments:

Usually, Conda is used when one needs binary package management, and installation with pip fails because of the build requirements that cannot be successfully completed with the tools and authorizations one has in their BAS dev space.

👉At the time of writing this post, using Conda might require additional commercial licenses from Anaconda, Inc. if downloading their tools and/or packages from their `default` channel. This might be a valid case for you, but this blog post covers only the use of the community-driven `conda-forge` channel, and the minimum tools required to use it. To the best of my knowledge, I discuss only the technical setup here, but you might need to check any license implications for the dependencies of a project you are working on.

Install miniforge

Follow the installation steps, for example from https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge?tab=readme-ov-file#unix-like-platforms-macos-linux--wsl

Download and run the installation script.

curl --location --remote-name --output-dir ~/tmp "https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-$(uname)-$(uname -m).sh"

bash ~/tmp/Miniforge3-$(uname)-$(uname -m).sh -b

 Configure conda

Activate conda and its base environment.

eval "$(/home/user/miniforge3/bin/conda shell.$(basename "${SHELL}") hook)"

 Initialize conda (it will add the shell's integration).

conda init

To prevent the conda's `base` environment from being activated on startup (because it will be taken care of by the Python extension), run the following command:

conda config --set auto_activate_base false

For changes to take effect, close and re-open your current shell.

Update conda's base environment to the latest packages from the community-maintained conda-forge channel.

conda update -n base --all --yes

You can also use the faster mamba command instead of conda. Both are parts of the Miniforge installation.

Point Python extension to your Conda executable

In Terminal, check the location of the conda command, which should be something like /home/user/miniforge3/condabin/conda:

which conda

 In Settings, open python.condaPath and switch to the Remote tab. Input the value.

Create a .conda environment in your project

Open your project folder in BAS.

From the command palette, start the command Python: Create Environment..., then Conda environment type...

...and select the required Python version from the list:

You should see the message that the environment is created and set as the active one for the project.

Open a new Terminal session, and you should see the `.conda` environment set.

You can check the list of environments with the command:

conda env list

Install IPyKernel in your .conda environment

Unlike in a "venv" virtual environment, the Python extension does not automatically install IPyKernel in a conda environment. You need to install it manually.

In Terminal, run the command 

conda install ipykernel --yes

Check with the command

conda list ipykernel

Select the .conda env in your notebook

Now, you can open your project's Jupyter notebook, select the .conda environment, and execute the code 🤓

You should be ready to work with conda-forge in SAP Business Application Studio now!

Please share your tips in the comments!

------

-Vitaliy, aka @Sygyzmundovych

entry.title: Re: No Assignment Group in Ariba CIM for central Invoice...
entry.content:
Hi @ChristianHeck 

Thanks for providing the screenshots and details, it’s really helpful. I located your scenario on the official SAP Community, and here’s what was confirmed:

In reference to SAP documentation and community posts, it clearly states that the Assignment Group field in the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app does depend on groups being assigned in the Central Invoice Management (CIM) system via Cloud Identity Services (IAS).

However, simply synchronizing the groups and users from IAS does not guarantee the Assignment Group will be recognized in the Fiori app. The aggregation rules must be configured too.           No Assignment Group in Ariba CIM for central Invoice Management App

If the transformation logic or CIM group mapping is misconfigured, then groups even if they begin with CIM_may not filter properly.

However, you are on the right path with IAS user and group synchronization, but I found that the groups are not appearing because assignment group rules haven’t been set up in CIM.

To fix the issue I suggest you carry out the following:

  1. In your IAS transformation, verify that you are mapping the group.id values properly to the CIM_... The format expected by Ariba CIM orange outlines suggest schema mismatches.
  2. In Ariba Central Invoice Management, go to Configure Assignment Group Rules and create rules mapping your supplier invoices to the CIM_ group names and users.

Once the transformation and assignment group rules are correctly configured, your CIM_ groups should appear in the “Assignment Group” filter dropdown in the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom API based on BO with custom (read) logic
entry.content:
Thank you for your question, @EgbertVenema.

By now you may have found an answer elsewhere. Still, your question gives me the opportunity to try an AI-based response I solicited from Joule for Consultants, SAP's new-ish chat bot for implementers:

"Custom API Implementation Using Business Objects

You can use a combination of existing Business Object (BO) interfaces and custom CRUD methods, including custom read logic, in SAP's ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP). RAP offers both managed and unmanaged implementation types for business objects, with managed implementations automatically handling CRUD operations through the RAP framework and unmanaged implementations requiring manual code [1][2].

Managed BO Implementation:

  • The RAP framework automatically handles CRUD operations, allowing developers to focus on business logic[1].
  • You can modify the save sequence for specific use cases, such as adding custom save procedures[3].

Unmanaged BO Implementation:

  • Requires manual implementation of transactional logic in ABAP classes, offering full control over database operations and allowing integration of legacy code like BAPIs[2].
  • This approach is suitable for integrating existing business logic and handling complex interactions[4].

For your need to adjust the read logic in cloud environments, both methods can be applied, but if more flexibility is needed, incorporating custom read logic with unmanaged implementation might be preferred. Using managed implementation with additional or unmanaged save options allows customization in standard interactions.

A hybrid approach leveraging managed BOs with unmanaged save can also be considered to balance agility with the need for specific customizations[1][3]."

If this response was helpful to you, please mark it accordingly. Thank you.

entry.title: Re: update field of interna table from another internal t...
entry.content:
Thank you for your request, @vieet .

I am aware this might be late, and you probably got an answer to your question elsewhere by now. But it gives me an opportunity to try out a new AI chat bot we now have available for our partners and customers, Joule for Consultants. Her is Joule's take on your question: 
"Modern ABAP Syntax for Updating Internal Tables

To optimize performance and avoid the traditional LOOP-ENDLOOP construct, you can use the ABAP 7.4 and 7.5 syntax enhancements which simplify internal table manipulation. Below are a couple of approaches you can consider:

  1. Using Filter and LOOP Expressions: You can use filter expressions to find the relevant entries, then apply a FOR expression to update the fields.

     
1 DATA(result) = FILTER #( lt_final USING KEY key WHERE bukrs = bukrs AND belnr = belnr AND gjahr = gjahr AND buzei = buzei AND lifnr = lifnr ).
2
3 LOOP AT nt_final ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL().
4  UPDATE lt_final SET lt_final[ sy-tabix ]-remarks = -remarks WHERE lines( result ) > 0.
5 ENDLOOP.

  • Using FOR and VALUE Expressions: The FOR expression combined with VALUE can efficiently iterate and modify table entries without a loop.

     
1 lt_final = VALUE #( FOR ls_final IN lt_final
2                    LET matched = FILTER #( nt_final USING KEY key WHERE bukrs = ls_final-bukrs AND belnr = ls_final-belnr AND gjahr = ls_final-gjahr )
3                    IN ( remarks = COND #( WHEN lines( matched ) > 0 THEN ls_final-remarks ELSE ls_final-remarks ) ) ).

Here, COND helps decide whether to update the remarks based on a matching filter. This approach minimizes loop overhead and directly updates entries as needed.

These methods utilize advanced syntax features in ABAP versions 7.4 and 7.5, helping to improve code readability and performance [1]."   

Please verify AI-based responses. Try out and test your code based on this recommendation thoroughly.
If this answered your request, please mark the response accordingly. Thank you.

请参阅下方的简体中文回复。请注意，此翻译和回复是借助生成式人工智能生成的。在实施之前，请根据您的用途核实该回复内容。如果此回复满足您的请求，请相应地进行标记。谢谢。

Translation to English:

The question is asking: "Is there an API that allows external systems to query [automatic account determination]? Or, is there a CDS View that can be used for automatic account determination?"

Response in English:

Yes, SAP provides options for automatic account determination through CDS views and APIs. You can use specific CDS views like the I_CAAcctDetnTransKey for account determination transaction keys, which help define the type of automatic posting required in financial accounting. This CDS view can support various business scenarios by providing transaction keys needed for account determination [1]. Additionally, creating custom CDS views for external API use is supported in SAP, allowing integration with external systems [2].

Response in Chinese:

是的，SAP 提供了通过 CDS 视图和 API 实现自动科目决定的选项。可以使用特定的 CDS 视图，例如 I_CAAcctDetnTransKey，该视图提供科目的决定交易键，有助于财务会计中的自动入账 [1]。此外，SAP 支持为外部 API 使用创建自定义 CDS 视图，从而实现与外部系统的集成 [2]。

entry.title: Re: In SAP CDS Views, the global search functionality is...
entry.content:
Thank you for your request, @Debashis2.

The following response is AI generated by SAP's "Joule for Consultants" chat bot. Please verify the response, accordingly.

"

Workaround for Global Search in CDS Views for Calculated Fields

Global search functionality in SAP CDS views does not support calculated or derived fields directly due to limitations in search annotations. Searching a calculated field is not feasible, as SAP allows only persisted fields in the database to be search-enabled [1].

To workaround these limitations, consider implementing the following options:

  1. Persist Calculated Values: If feasible, persist the calculated values in a physical field within the underlying database table. By storing the calculated values, you can then use search annotations like @Search.searchable: true and @Search.defaultSearchElement: true directly on persisted fields.

  2. Custom Filtering: Instead of a global search, introduce the calculated fields in a filter list. This approach allows users to filter data based on calculated attributes in the UI [1].

  3. Text Search with Associations: Use association with other CDS views that allow text searches, like I_TextObjectPlainLongText, to enable complex search scenarios. This requires additional setup in maintaining view associations but can provide a workaround where necessary [2].

These methods provide alternatives to achieve the desired search capabilities within the limitations of CDS views for calculated data."  

If this response answers your question, please mark it accordingly. Thank you.

entry.title: CPI Integration with BW/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction

The below blog provides an overview of setting up a simple CPI integration to post data to a SAP BW/4HANA on-premise instance.  I have included an explanation of how to achieve this in both postman and SAP Cloud Integration.  I have also included references to helpful blogs you can refer to for additional details.

Set up in BW

Create DSO in BW

Ensure 'Write Interface Enabled' attribute is set.

Add fields to DSO

 

Download URL's shown on DSO

Get Structure

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze

Get Sample Data

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze/sampleData{?records,seed}

Send Data

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze/dataSend{?request,datapid}

Open Request

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze/requests

Close Request

https://server:port/sap/bw4/v1/push/dataStores/da_maze/requests/{request}/close{?error}

 

Using DSO in Postman

For Info can query DSO structure

Or see an example json payload

 

Post data in postman:

Step 1: Fetch CSRF token

Add header for x-csrf-token = fetch, set Authorization to basic Auth

Response header will contain the csrf token

Step 2: Send Data to BW

Add header x-csrf-token and set value returned by call in Step 1 (found in the response header)

Set body to message to post to BW (xml in this example)

Response back

Example JSON POST

 

Data Post example in CPI

The process below mirrors the process done previously in postman to post data to BW

 

Against the Integration flow set HTTP session

 

  1. Start Timer - Schedule set to Run Once
  2. Set Csrf token header

3. Make http call to get csrf token returned (note that in this example an on-premise BW is being called so virtual host/port have been set in cloud connector)

Make sure Headers are both passed to the call and returned

4. Handle Cookies - The initial csrf call returns an header called 'set-cookie', unfortunately the call to post the data requires an header called 'cookie'.  The groovy script converts the format and name.  More details can be found in https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/sci/3361897820.html?locale=en-US

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) {

    def headers = message.getHeaders();

    def cookies = headers.get("set-cookie");

    message.setHeader("cookie", String.join("; ", cookies));

return message;

}        

5. Set content type and payload of data post

6. HTTP call to post data to BW

 

Referenced Blogs:

Integrating with BW

From <https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-bw-4hana-write-interface-enabled-adso-connected-to-a-3rd-party-tool/ba-p/13482277>

Example CPI to BW

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-cloud-platform-integration-cpi-to-push-data-into-sap-bw-4hana/ba-p/13418310

Issues with x-csrf not working see below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/x-csrf-token-with-on-premises-sap-system-using-http-receiver-adapter/ba-p/13533518

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/sci/3361897820.html?locale=en-US

entry.title: Re: License model of IAG
entry.content:
Hi, IAG license is bought by the customer deciding "a priori" if they use the integration edition or the standard one. It is not something that is measured after service activation and it is not based on any customer configuration.

The license metric for Integration edition is number of systems connected. The one for standard edition, instead, is based on resources (simply put, on number of monitored users).

Hope it helps

P.s. you can always check those information in the SAP Trust Center. For instance, supplements for IAG include information about the license metrics. You can find more information at the following link: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements/cloud/cloud-services.html?sort=latest_desc&search=Supplement%20identity%20access%20governance&tag=language:english-usa

entry.title: Building Collaborative Microservices in Python with FastAPI: Echo & Reverse Agents (Beginner -Part1)
entry.content:
Microservices encourage us to build distributed systems consisting of small, specialized components that communicate seamlessly. In this post, let’s explore a simple yet illustrative example: Agent-A and Agent-B, two FastAPI-based Python microservices that interact in real-time.

We'll see how Agent-A receives a request, calls Agent-B, and returns a transformed response—demonstrating the foundations of service-to-service HTTP communication.

The Objective

We want to create:

  • Agent-B: A service that reverses text.
  • Agent-A: A service that takes a string, sends it to Agent-B for reversal, and returns the reversed string as a response.

Both services are built with FastAPI and use Pydantic for data validation.

Meet Agent-B: The Reverse Service

Let's begin by looking at agent_b.py. It’s a minimal service that exposes one endpoint that takes a string and returns it reversed.

from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel
import os

PORT = int(os.getenv("AGENT_B_PORT", 8001))
app = FastAPI(title="Agent-B")

class ReverseRequest(BaseModel):
    text: str

class ReverseResponse(BaseModel):
    source: str
    reversed: str

@app.post("/reverse", response_model=ReverseResponse)
def reverse(req: ReverseRequest):
    return ReverseResponse(source="Agent-B", reversed=req.text[::-1])

Meet Agent-A: The Forwarding Echo Service

Now, let’s look at agent_a.py. While it’s called an "echo" service, it doesn’t simply echo back input. Instead, it forwards the input to Agent-B, receives the reversed string, and returns that. This demonstrates microservice orchestration.

agent_a.py

from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel
import httpx
import os

PORT = int(os.getenv("AGENT_A_PORT", 8000))
B_URL = os.getenv("AGENT_B_URL", "http://localhost:8001")
app = FastAPI(title="Agent-A")

class EchoRequest(BaseModel):
    text: str

class EchoResponse(BaseModel):
    source: str
    echoed: str

@app.post("/echo", response_model=EchoResponse)
async def echo(req: EchoRequest):
    # Forward the text to Agent-B
    async with httpx.AsyncClient() as client:
        r = await client.post(f"{B_URL}/reverse", json={"text": req.text})
        r.raise_for_status()
        reversed_text = r.json()["reversed"]
    # Respond with what Agent-B returned
    return EchoResponse(source="Agent-A", echoed=reversed_text)

 

Running Both Agents

  1. Start Agent-B:

    uvicorn agent_b:app --port 8001

  2. Start Agent-A:

    uvicorn agent_a:app --port 8000

     

Testing the System

Let’s see the microservices in action with curl:

curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/echo \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{"text":"hello A2A"}'

Response:

{
  "source": "Agent-A",
  "echoed": "A2A olleh"
}

What happened?

  • The request hits Agent-A’s /echo.
  • Agent-A calls Agent-B’s /reverse with the payload.
  • Agent-B reverses the string.
  • Agent-A returns Agent-B’s output* as its own "echoed" field.

How to Extend This Example

  • Add Logging/Tracing: See the flow end-to-end.
  • Synchronous vs Asynchronous calls: Both are possible; here httpx with async enables efficient concurrency.
  • Error Handling: Add more robust logic in production.
  • Authentication: Secure the endpoints as needed.
  • More Agents: Build a family of collaborating services!

Conclusion

With just a few lines of Python and FastAPI, we built two collaborating microservices with clear responsibilities and simple interaction via HTTP. This pattern underpins many real-world distributed architectures, making it a great learning foundation for building maintainable and scalable systems.

Try extending these agents on your own use case!

entry.title: HOW TO CHANGE MASS OBJECTS/TABLE BY MASS T-CODE?
entry.content:
As we have tools to create mass data on SAP, such as LSMW (for migration purposes), etc. However, MASS is created by and used SAP S4/HANA => in order to do similar changes to all of the fields of an object. For example, you want to mass change the texts of material, or you want to do mass change to similar materials to all the sales order, or you want to mark delivery completed to all Purchase orders, etc



In this case, we have to know each Object Type that related to the data we want to change. For example, in this case, we want to change the Sales Order, so we choose BUS2032

For the object we want to use and want to change, we can check on the t-code MASSOBJ to input the Object we want to change and details related to the Object. Since using MASSOBJ t-code is cross-client, please be careful do additional setup to this tcode. As I can show you the detail related to BUS2032- Sales order:

 

 

 

As you can see, the detail tables/fields of Sales order could be seen here easily.

Let’s get back to the MASS t-code.

 

  1. Input object type that needs to change 
  2. As you can see, there are a lot of options to mass change the sales order, at tables level, or fields level

    Table level

     

     


    Field level

     

  3. In this example, we will mass change header data of Sales orders => click execute

     



    As you can see, we also have options that “Import Data from File” for large amount of data that we need to change

  4. Input the needed data here, as you can see, MASS do support to create new data



    We can go through the details and see how the change applied by click on “Display All Records” or Chg. In Background.

     


    Chg. In Background is used in this case.

  5. As you can see, there are many fields related to Sales Order Header Level as imagine below. In this case, I choose the reference field:

  6. As you can see below, we can do mass changes as below
    .

     

    I will input "DAVE" as New value


    Click Transfer => Field get updated

  7. As you can see on the table view and on the log changes of Sales order:

    Change log below:


As MASS tool is a very powerful tool/t-code to change mass object, please keep in mind that this change could impact both master data and transactional data. You could engage it first on testing environment before running it on production to make sure the field you change is correct.

Thank you and have a nice day,

Dave

entry.title: Re: CER006

entry.title: Re: sapcs?serverInfo
entry.content:
I eventually got this figured out after trying multiple approaches.

C:\usr\sap\KP9\SYS\profile\cs.conf       is the correct location for my Content Server 7.54 configuration file

The Software Provisioning Tool created the entire path, but they did not create the cs.conf file.  It would have been nice if they had also created an empty cs.conf file with a comment in the file telling me to use appropriate SAP Notes to manually convert my old ContentServer.ini configuration settings to the appropriate syntax for the new Content Server 7.54.

The problem with the http://<my_server_name>:1090/sapcs?serverInfo not working was due to a non-existent cs.conf file.  Additionally, I learned later, that the http://<my_server_name>:1090/sapcs?serverInfo test will not work if cs.conf has "Security=1" set

entry.title: Request for Method to Delete or Adjust Transactions in In-House Bank Account Balances
entry.content:
We would like to confirm if there is a way to delete or adjust transactions registered in the in-house bank account balances.

When importing MT940 statements, we update the virtual account balances based on the information provided in the memo line.
However, in this case, incorrect information was included in the memo line, which resulted in an unintended transaction being created in the in-house bank account.

We would like to know if there is a way to correct this transaction.
For example, is it possible to create a reversal transaction for the same amount with the opposite sign, or to invalidate the transaction in some way?

Thank you for your support.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Request for Method to Delete or Adjust Transactions i...
entry.content: You can reverse the wrongly posted bank statement items in the Reprocess Bank Statement Items and Reprocess Lockbox Items app. Kindly refer to the SAP Help Portal How to Reverse Postings

entry.title: Re: sapcs?serverInfo
entry.content:
The original command, http://<my_server_name>:1090/ContentServer/ContentServer.dll?serverInfo, was still working because it was connecting to the old Content Server 6.5 which I had not stopped yet.

To get the new command, http://<my_server_name>:1090/sapcs?serverInfo to work, I had to correctly configure the new cs.conf file, stop the old Content Server 6.5 and start the new Content Server 7.54.

In addition, I had to have Security=0 to get the http:// commands to work.
